about.info: Our database of resources benefits from information collected by these organizations:
about.title: About this site

front-page.p2: We provide information on resources such as free meals, food, legal assistance, and medical help.
front-page.p3: Start by selecting where you are and what you're looking for.

p4.text: We are affiliated with Stanford's {0} and {1} and are extremely grateful to Bill Behrman, Sara Altman, and Cheryl Phillips for their ongoing support and advice.

p1.text: We are a volunteer-driven, open-source project to help communities navigate the COVID crisis by providing information on public resources. This project began as a {0}, and now provides information on more resources such as locations and schedules for free meals, food assistance, legal assistance, and medical help.

p2.text: The development for this project was adapted from {0}.

p3.text: You can find more information on the project, including the source code for replicating the project, from our {0}.

about.about-us-sources:
Our database of information benefits from data collected by the following organizations:
USDA SNAP Store locator
USDA WIC Store locator
Second Harvest of Silicon Valley
Stanford Pediatric Advocacy

We have a team of amazing volunteers who verify the data and collect any additional information such as additional Covid-19 senior hours, safe curbside pick-up options etc.
about.about-us-disclaimer: This Bay Area Resources project is purely volunteer-driven. We have a team of humans collecting and verifying data from diverse sources. We do our best to keep all the information on the site as up-to-date as possible, however we cannot guarantee that the information is 100% accurate.

pebt.header: Food benefits for kids who get free or reduced-price meals.

ux_study.text_main: We want to learn more about what is top of mind for you at this time and get your input on how to improve the website.
ux_study.text_sub: If you are selected for interviewing,  all sessions will be conducted remotely via phone / video chat, and  we will compensate you for your time.

faq.title: Welcome to Know Your Rights
faq.home_help_text: Select an area below to find out more about your rights.
faq.subcategory_help_text: Click on the questions below to expand answers.

questions.question: What should I do?
answer: Generally the protocols for police arrests are not different from pre-COVID times, except that they are more likely to issue summons in the field rather than bringing detainees into a station for booking (source).
You can find regular know-your-rights information for when you are stopped by the police at the ACLU Northern California Chapter’s website.

questions.question: What is the status of the courts?
answer: During a public health emergency like COVID-19, courts prioritize critical cases (i.e. bail hearings, emergency protective orders such as in domestic violence and child abuse cases, and contested quarantine and isolation orders) over other caseloads (source).
You can find the most updated information about operation policies on each court's website for COVID-19 news. We list a few here for you.
Alameda County Court Website
Santa Clara County Court Website
San Mateo County Court Website

questions.question: How can I pay bail during COVID-19?
answer: On April 6, the Judicial Council of California adopted 11 Emergency Rules and established that bail for infractions will be set at $0.00, while bail for technical violations of felony probation, Post Release Community Supervision (PRCS), or parole will be set at $5,000.00. The rules are repealed on June 10, but counties like Alameda have adopted their own “zero bail” emergency bail schedule.
See the "Bail Fund Resources" section.

content.title: Someone I know has been arrested

questions.question: Can I attend their court hearing?
answer: Since most matters are being heard remotely through court call and a public access, listen-only line is also available. You can also check the most updated information on each court's website for COVID-19 news.
See the "Status of courts" section for a list of website addresses.

questions.question: How can I help them apply for bail fund?
answer: See the "Bail Fund Resources" section.

questions.question: Can I visit them in incarceration?
answer: As part of CDCR’s COVID-19 prevention efforts, normal visiting will be canceled statewide until further notice. This includes non-contact visits, family visits, and the Division of Juvenile Justice. You can find updates on the CDCR website for visitation information.

content.title: I am looking for bail fund resources during COVID

questions.question: I’m looking for bail bonds for protesters.
answer: There are many organizations that provide bail fund resources for protesters. We list a few here for you:
National Lawyers Guild (NLG) San Francisco Chapter Hotline:
(415) 285-1011 (for protestors arrested)
(916) 500-4NLG (for friends and family) please provide the full name and a birthday of the arrested person.
National bail fund network's list of protest bail funds in California.

questions.question: I’m looking for bail resources for other charges.
answer: You can find bail resources at the National Bail Fund Network’s website.

questions.question: How can I stay safe as a survivor during the COVID-19 pandemic?
answer: Here are hotlines and support tips for survivors during COVID-19:
For family and relationship stress
For gender-based violence
Here are two websites with tips for survivors on staying safe during COVID-19:
National Domestic Violence Hotline
Sanctuary for Families
Here is general information for survivors who are currently in a relationship with their abuser

questions.question: What additional resources and support services are available during the COVID-19 pandemic?
answer: The Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (CARES Act) provides for an array of resources, including unemployment insurance, additional funds for serving survivors of domestic violence, and housing protections. More information about these resources can be found here:
The National Network to End Domestic Violence
Futures Without Violence
Survivors may face barriers obtaining relief payments provided by the CARES Act. The National Network to End Domestic Violence has outlined processes for how survivors can obtain their payments.

questions.question: Can I be evicted during the COVID-19 pandemic?
answer: Your state or locality may have put a pause on evictions during the COVID-19 pandemic. While these “eviction moratoriums” may have exceptions allowing for evictions due to criminal activity or other lease violations, domestic violence survivors have additional protections from evictions. Information on these protections and how to access them can be found here.

questions.question: I have a court appearance during the COVID-19 pandemic. How should I prepare?
answer: This resource provides general information about the court process for survivors who are not represented by lawyers.

questions.question: Where can I find information on court policies during COVID-19?
answer: Some courthouses have closed or postponed hearings due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Information on court closures and answers to frequently asked questions involving courts and COVID-19 can be found here.

questions.question: I am an employee experiencing violence or threats of violence in my workplace. What can I do?
answer: The protections available to employees experiencing violence or threats of violence in the workplace are generally the same as pre-COVID-19. There are steps that you and your employer can take to address violence in your workplace, including filing a complaint against your employer with the government, and filing for a workplace violence restraining order.
More information on these and other steps and on different kinds of sexual harassment and workplace violence can be found here:
General information
Filing for a workplace restraining order in California

questions.question: Can I get time off from work to go to court or to get resources and/or support?
answer: Survivors of domestic violence and sexual assault are entitled to job-guaranteed time off from work to testify in court as a witness or to ensure the health and safety of themselves and their children. Employees may also be entitled to job-guaranteed leave to obtain support and services, such as medical attention.
More information on who qualifies for job-guaranteed leave can be found here
A helpline, informational videos, and sample letters and forms can be found here

questions.question: I am no longer working or have to leave my job to protect myself and/or my family. Am I eligible for unemployment insurance?
answer: If you are a survivor who has to quit their job because you are harmed by or are afraid of being harmed by an abuser, a perpetrator of sexual assault, or a stalker at work, you may still be entitled to unemployment insurance benefits.
You can find information on eligibility for benefits and the steps you must take to obtain benefits here

questions.question: Where can I find general employment resources for survivors?
answer: Here you can find a list of links and phone numbers for national and state resources, resources on sexual assault, and resources for state employees.
Here you can find an employment rights toolkit for survivors.
Here is a factsheet on the rights of survivors and caregivers of survivors related to job protection, wage replacement, and accommodations and equality in the workplace.

questions.question: I am a survivor of domestic violence on a military installation, and/or I have experienced domestic violence or child abuse by a military service member. What support services and resources are available to me?
answer: Information on domestic violence in the military and the process of obtaining a military protective order (which can protect survivors from abusers who are service members) is available here.

questions.question: I am an immigrant. What support services and resources are available to me?
answer: WomensLaw.org strongly recommends that you consult with an immigration lawyer with relevant expertise and provides information on VAWA for abuse victims, U Visas for crime victims, T Visas for trafficking victims, asylum, and refugee status. See more here.

questions.question: I am deaf or hard of hearing. What support services and resources are available to me?
answer: All Hands On has created this video in American Sign Language on resources for D/HOH survivors.

questions.question: I am a young person. What support services and resources are available to me?
answer: A hotline and further information for youth survivors can be found on the LoveisRespect.org website (see the “Get Help” tab)

questions.question: I identify as LGBTQ. What support services and resources are available to me?
answer: LGBTQ and HIV-affected survivors can report violence, get support, and find legal help using the resources from the Anti-Violence Project here.

questions.question: I am Native American. What support services and resources are available to me?
answer: A support hotline, information about abuse in Indian Country and Alaska, safety tips, and additional resources from StrongHearts Native Helpline can be found here.

questions.question: I am Latinx. What support services and resources are available to me?
answer: A bilingual support helpline, information about abuse and immigrant rights, support organizations, and additional resources from Case de Esperanza can be found here.

questions.question: Where can I find resources on mediation and legal services concerning sexual harassment?
answer: Survivors of sexual harassment may seek resolution through mediation or legal remedies. Information on mediation and a list of legal and technical resources is available here.

questions.question: Am I eligible to file for a domestic violence restraining order? How can I get one?
answer: In California, you can file for a domestic violence restraining order if you or your minor child has been the victim of domestic violence from a spouse or former spouse; a person you are dating or used to date; the mother or father of your child; a person related to you by blood, marriage, or adoption; or a “cohabitant” of your home. Further information on eligibility, the protections provided by a restraining order, and the steps for obtaining one can be found here.

questions.question: I have a criminal record related to my abuse. Does my employer have to see it? Can I have it cleared?
answer: Legal Aid at Work provides know-your-rights information on what your employer can ask about your criminal record, whether you can clear your criminal record, whether you can get your conviction dismissed, how to answer employment questions, and how to have a restraining order against you removed here.

questions.question: Where can I find information on gun laws and whether or not my abuser can have a gun?
answer: Information on federal gun laws
Information on California gun laws

questions.question: Where can I find information about custody, visitation, and child support?
answer: WomensLaw.org provides video blogs on custody, visitation, child support, and parental kidnapping narrated in Spanish with English subtitles that can be found here.

questions.question: Where can I find additional resources and general information?
answer: A list of national hotlines can be found here
See “Resources for Survivors” for additional resources here
California-specific lists of advocates and shelters, information on finding a lawyer, courthouse locations, and contact information for sheriff departments can be found here
Additional domestic violence organizations in California can be found here

content.title: Am I eligible to receive unemployment benefits?

questions.question: How do I check my eligibility status?
answer: You can check this website to confirm eligibility. Please see below for additional details.

For general information, visit the Employment Development Department of the State of California (EDD)’s Eligibility Requirements and FAQ - Eligibility pages, and on Legal Aid at Work’s Coronavirus - FAQ page.
You must have:
(1) "earned enough wages during the base period to establish a claim," and
(2) been in "satisfactory immigration status and authorized to work in the United States when earning the wages."
Additionally, the California EDD outlines the following requirements that must ALL* be met in order to be eligible to file a claim:
(1) Totally or partially unemployed.
(2) Unemployed through no fault of your own.
(3) Physically able to work.
(4) Available for work.
(5) Ready and willing to accept work immediately.
* Please see the below regarding specific situations in which you may still be eligible.

questions.question: What if I quit my job?
answer: If there was: (1) good cause for leaving, and (2) you made all reasonable attempts to keep your job (such as requesting a leave of absence or transfer), you may still be eligible.
Good cause can include unsafe working conditions, a medical doctor’s advice, or the protection of yourself or your child from domestic violence.

questions.question: What if I am taking care of a seriously ill family member or bonding with your new child?
answer: You are not eligible for unemployment insurance benefits, but you may be eligible for support through California’s Paid Family Leave (PFL) program.
Caring for a new child includes the birth of a child, adoption, or foster care placement.

questions.question: What if I was fired for misconduct?
answer: You are likely not eligible if your employer proves misconduct.

questions.question: What if I am sick or injured?
answer: You are not eligible for unemployment insurance benefits, but you may be able to file a Disability Insurance claim.

questions.question: What if I am a small business owner, self-employed worker, or independent contractor (among other categories)?
answer: You may still be eligible if your unemployment or partial unemployment is due to COVID-19. Read more about the Pandemic Unemployment Assistance program here.

content.title: How much can I receive in unemployment benefits?

questions.question: Where can I find an estimate of how much I can receive in employment benefits?
answer: For an estimate, see: Calculator - Unemployment Insurance. Please see below for additional details.

questions.question: What is the range of benefits I may receive?
answer: If you are eligible* to receive unemployment benefits, your benefits will range from $40 to $560 a week.
Between March 29th, 2020 and July 25th, 2020, you are also eligible to receive another $600 per week due to the Pandemic Additional Compensation program.

You can typically only collect “up to 26 weeks of regular state Unemployment Insurance (UI) benefits within 12-month benefit year,” but under the Pandemic Emergency Unemployment Compensation (PEUC) program, you can collect “an additional 13 weeks of payments if you’ve used all of your available UI benefits.
* See the “Am I eligible to receive unemployment benefits?” FAQ.

content.title: How do I file for unemployment benefits?

questions.question: Where do I go to file a claim?
answer: See: Filing a Claim OR call 800-300-5616 (English), 800-326-8937 (Spanish), 800-547-3506 (Cantonese), or 866-303-0706 (Mandarin).

questions.question: What should I keep in mind when filing a claim?
answer: Please note that you must certify for benefits every two weeks. Please also note any COVID-19 Temporary Exceptions listed on the Filing a Claim page.

questions.question: What if I have a disability?
answer: For information about reasonable accommodations during COVID-19, visit Legal Aid at Work’s Disabilities in the Workplace: Reasonable Accommodation page.

questions.question: My employer is treating me differently. What can I do?
answer: You can file a charge for discrimination. For more information, visit Legal Aid at Work’s How to File a Charge of Discrimination page.

questions.question: How do I receive income when I am sick with COVID-19? / I am worried about losing my job because I am sick with COVID-19.
answer: You are entitled to Paid Sick Days. You may be able for State Disability Insurance or workers’ compensation benefits. For more information, visit Legal Aid at Work’s Coronavirus - FAQ page.

questions.question: I need to care for a family member or friend who is sick with COVID-19.
answer: You may be eligible for Paid Sick Days or Paid Family Leave. For more information, visit Legal Aid at Work’s Coronavirus - FAQ page.

questions.question: I need time off to take care of my child because daycare and schools are closed due to COVID-19.
answer: Depending on the size of your employer, you may be entitled to paid leave. You may also be eligible for Unemployment Insurance. For more information, visit Legal Aid at Work’s Coronavirus - FAQ page.

content.title: Where can I find more information?

questions.question: I want more information on unemployment benefits in California during COVID-19.
answer: Please see the Fisher Phillips California Employers Blog’s guide.

questions.question: I want to view video overviews of unemployment benefits in California during COVID-19.
answer: The LA Law Library’s video
The Employment Development Department of the State of California (EDD)’s video

questions.question: I want more information on Pandemic Unemployment Assistance.
answer: See the Disaster Legal Assistance Collaborative’s page from the Neighborhood Legal Services of Los Angeles County.

questions.question: I want more information on collecting unemployment benefits in California.
answer: For information on the amount and duration of unemployment compensation in California, see this page.

questions.question: I need general information and mutual aid resources for immigrant and migrant communities during COVID-19. Where can I find information for the Bay Area?
answer: General resources gathered by Eastoaklanddreamers.org
Financial help for immigrants in the Bay Area
County of San Mateo
Contra Costa County

questions.question: Where can I find information for California?
answer: COVID-19 Guidance for Immigrant Californians prepared by state government
Resource Guide prepared by California Immigrant Policy Center
Resources gathered by California Immigrant Youth Justice Alliance
COVID-19 Pandemic: Information and Resources for Immigrant Communities in the Central Valley
Resources for Undocumented Californians prepared by the Unity Council

questions.question: Where can I find nationwide information?
answer: Tangible Support for Undocumented communities during COVID-19 prepared by Immigrants Rising
Informed Immigrant website
Nationwide Resources (including financial, medical, mutual aid, legal, food resources and resource list)
National Immigration Law Center website
Resources gathered by iAmerica
Resources gathered by Asian Americans Advancing Justice – Asian Law Caucus

questions.question: Where can I check the status of immigration courts and agencies?
answer: For San Francisco, you can find the status of immigration courts and agencies in the following websites:
Updates by SFILEN.org (San Francisco Immigrant Legal & Education Network), SFILDC.org (San Francisco Immigrant Legal Defense Collaborative), SFRRN.org (San Francisco Rapid Response Network)
San Francisco Immigration Court
For nationwide information, you can find the status of immigration courts and agencies in the following websites:
USCIS Response to COVID-19
Executive Office for Immigration Review (EOIR) Operational Status During Coronavirus Pandemic

questions.question: What additional measures are being taken by courts during COVID-19?
answer: You can visit these websites for information on courts’ additional measures:
COVID-19 USCIS Office Closures Guidance
Immigration Measures in Response to COVID-19 prepared by Bay Area Legal Aid

questions.question: Are there any other resources on court access?
answer: Visit Immigrant Legal Resource Center’s website

questions.question: How are DACA renewals currently being processed?
answer: You can find information about DACA renewals during COVID-19 here: Frequently Asked Questions about DACA Renewals in the Middle of COVID-19 Crisis

questions.question: Are there any other resources on DACA renewals and proceedings?
answer: DACA Updates During the Coronavirus Crisis prepared by Informed Immigrant

questions.question: How can I protect myself from getting sick?
answer: You can visit the following website for relevant tips on health protection: Immigrant Communities Guidance by California Department of Public Health

questions.question: What if I do not have health insurance or am undocumented?
answer: You can find tips for uninsured and undocumented immigrants in the following websites:
If you don’t have health insurance
Accessing COVID-19 Testing & Treatment, Tips for Uninsured and Undocumented Californians

questions.question: Does the public charge rule apply to me?
answer: You can visit the following websites to see if public charge rule applies to you:
Protecting Immigrant Families’ updates
California Health Care Foundation’s updates

questions.question: Are there any other resources on health care?
answer: Latino Coalition for a Healthy California

questions.question: Will my immigration status affect my ability to apply for unemployment benefits?
answer: If you were authorized to work when you lost your job and are authorized to work now, your application for unemployment will not be affected (source).
If not, you are ineligible for unemployment benefits.

questions.question: Am I eligible for CARES relief (the recent $1,200 payments from the government)?
answer: To be eligible, you need to satisfy all of the following requirements (source):
You have a social security number;
You have a green card OR meet the “substantial presence test” (which requires that you spent the last three years living in the United States;
You filed taxes in 2018 or 2019, OR you receive social security.
If you are eligible, you should have received a check or direct deposit with your relief funds.
If you do not satisfy the above requirements, you are not eligible for CARES relief.

questions.question: Am I eligible to apply for Coronavirus Disaster Relief for Immigrants?
answer: To be eligible, you need to satisfy all of the following requirements (source):
You are undocumented;
You were ineligible for CARES relief (the recent $1,200 payments from the government);
You have experienced hardship due to COVID-19.
You can check the following website for related FAQs: California Department of Social Services website
If you do not satisfy the above requirements, you are not eligible for Coronavirus Disaster Relief for Immigrants.

questions.question: Are there any other kinds of relief I may be eligible for?
answer: You can refer to the following website for relevant information: A List of Relief Funds for Undocumented Workers in California, compiled by Legal Aid at Work

questions.question: Are there any other resources on employment, benefits and financial relief?
answer: You can visit this website for more information: COVID-19 Outbreak Resources and Information for Workers, compiled by California Labor Federation
